data.text: Contents
Introduction
In 2013/14, NHS England set an operational standard to ensure that no-one waits more than  weeks from referral to treatment (RTT).

Whilst there is an acknowledgement that there may be legitimate reasons for some waits, NHS England have set expectations that such long delays should be expected to trigger a review process, so that providers can understand the causes of these long waits and put in place processes to avoid them in future.
This procedure provides oversight and management of the process for undertaking a root cause analysis (RCA) and Clinical Harm Review (CHR) for any RTT pathway closed over 52 weeks.

Clinical harm can be defined as unintended injury resulting from or contributed to by medical care or delayed treatment that requires additional monitoring, treatment or hospitalisation or that results in death
When a case of clinical or psychological harm is found to have occurred, the Trust Incident and Duty of Candour process will be followed.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and
meets the needs of all individuals.
Scope

The purpose of this procedure is to provide guidance on the process for reporting and investigating the management of patients who have breached the national performance standard of 52 weeks on an RTT pathway.
Provide guidance on the process for the reporting and investigating of potential or actual harm caused.

The RCA undertaken as part of the incident process will take into account all contributory factors, including that a patient may choose to wait longer or clinically be unable to be seen or treated within these time frames.
The SOP aims to provide assurance that all avoidable pathway delays are monitored and actions implemented to reduce the risk of any future delays and patient harm
An RTT backlog is defined as over 60 days (2 months) from the time of patient treatment (clock stop).
Definitions

table_items.text: Executive Review Group - Clinically led group that determines the level of investigation required for incidents that have occurred. This group also signs off root cause analysis investigations and action plans as a result of serious incidents, never events and internal investigations.
Local Harm Review Panel - Clinically led panel to review/validate/action completed harm reviews and develop lessons learnt or actions for system where applicable

Root cause analysis (RCA) was developed for the health services to promote a systematic approach to the investigation of serious incidents. The RCA investigation will identify any underlying system and process issues that may have caused or contributed to the incident.
Serious Incident - an incident that occurred in relation to NHS-funded services and care resulting in unexpected or avoidable death, harm or injury to patient, carer, staff or visitor.

Key elements of procedural guideline
Process

table_items.text: Weekly access meetings will discuss all potential 52+ week pathways. Clinicians will still be able to escalate the need for a harm review on any patient below 52 weeks that they feel requires one regardless of the stage they are in their pathway.
To identify patients who require review.

a) The list of 52+ breach patients who have completed their pathway will be emailed to the relevant specialties and the harm review co-ordinator, once the monthly 52 week breaches have been confirmed. The harm review co- co-ordinator will report the breach on the incident reporting system (Appendix 5). The Divisions/Directorates will complete the harm review (Appendix 1 and 2). This must be done within 4 weeks. b) Patients on an incomplete RTT pathway of greater than 52 weeks will be clinically prioritised by the Directorates/Divisions to determine likelihood of harm, and expedite any patients at risk of harm. Clinical prioritisation is a mandated programme from NHSE/I. Clinicians will still be able to escalate the need for a harm review on any patient on a breached incomplete RTT pathway. All RTT 52+ week breaches will be monitored by the Service Managers and Divisional/Directorate Governance Managers/Facilitators, as part of the internal Governance processes.
Ensures accurate pathway guide to review

Lead clinician and managerial leads, through their own governance structure have 4 weeks to review timelines, assess and action counter measures for avoidable delays. Lead clinician to assess whether pathway delays have impacted on the patient's outcome and resulted in clinical and/or psychological harm. Once the form has been completed they will be sent to the Harm Review Co-ordinator to prepare for the Local Harm Review Panel.

The Harm Review Co-ordinator will prepare the agenda for the harm review panel, which will take place each week. Membership of this meeting is as per the Harm Review Panel Terms of Reference (Appendix 10). Following review of the patient pathway, should there be any significant findings or queries that require further detail, these will be relayed to the lead clinicians and managerial leads, via the Harm Review Co-ordinator, so further evidence can be provided. The harm review paperwork must be processed and presented at the local harm review panel within 4 weeks.

Share good practice and learning Any RCAs where the patient outcome is found to have been impacted and where the level of harm is assessed as moderate harm or above will be reviewed the Trust's Director Review Group where a decision on declaration will be made. Where moderate harm or above is confirmed, the Duty of Candour will be met.

The Harm Review Co-ordinator will prepare summary reports to the Site Leadership Team and CCG as required. All patients escalated from the harm review panel as having had, or potentially, had an instance of moderate or above, clinical or psychological harm will be escalated to the Patient Safety team for review at the Executive Review Group (ERG).

data.text: Incident reporting and review

5.2.1 Every breach incident requiring harm review must be notified Division/Directorate wide via the incident reporting system following notification of validated 52 week breaches  through  the  RTT  reporting  process  to  NHSE  England  distributed  by Analysis & Reporting team
5.2.2 The Service Managers of each specialty will be responsible for completing the review of each patient with the support of the lead Clinician for that patient's care.
5.2.3 Incidents reported where the harm has been initially assessed as moderate or above will be reviewed by the Executive Review Group (ERG).

5.2.4 Breaches and action points/plans will be shared at Senior Management Group, Divisional/Directorate performance meetings and Planned Care Board. Following this it will be shared with the Clinical Quality Review Group (CCG).
5.2.5 For breaches where moderate patient harm or above has been identified then the Duty of Candour process must be followed.
5.2.6 A representative of the CCG is invited to attend harm review meetings at agreed intervals.

5.2.7 The number of 52 week breaches by specialty will be a standing agenda item at the Planned  Care  Board.  The  Planned  Care  Board  will  receive  and  monitor  the Divisional/Directorate exception reports as a standing agenda item, ensuring action is taken to mitigate avoidable delays.

All clinical/non-clinical staff involved in RTT pathways will have specific induction in relation to the implementation of this procedure.

Appendix 6: Degree of harm RAG rating guidance table

table_items.text: There are two types of no harm incident: a) Impact prevented (i.e. a near miss): any adverse incident that had the potential to cause harm but was prevented, resulting in no harm to anyone b) Impact not prevented: any adverse incident that ran to completion but caused no harm to anyone.

Pathway found to be an administrative failing with no delay to patient Patient waited excessively for treatment but no harm was caused as a result of the wait Patient died of a different condition to that for which they were referred.
Defined as: Any event or circumstance resulting in minor changes to the original treatment plan and caused minimal harm.
Additional treatment and/or pain relief required Psychological impact of delayed treatment on the patient.

Defined as: (a) harm that requires a moderate increase in treatment, and; (b) significant, but not permanent, harm; A “moderate increase in treatment” means an unplanned change to the original treatment plan, an emergency admission for the same condition prior to treatment, extra time in hospital or as an outpatient, cancelling of treatment, transfer to another treatment area (such as intensive care), or prolonged psychological harm (prolonged in this context means waiting for treatment in excess of 52 weeks).

Multiple attendances to ED for the same condition (not admitted) Admitted via ED for the same condition Where the treatment plan is significantly different to the original treatment plan, requiring more recovery or protracted length of stay as a result.

Defined as: A permanent lessening of physiologic or intellectual functions, including organ or brain damage, that is related directly to the delay in managing the patient and not related to the condition for which the patient was referred.

What are you proposing to change?
The process has changed significantly since the previous SOP for RTT harm reviews was developed. The process was not the same across the MSE.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
We now have a more robust process which provides monitoring and assurance. The procedure now defines the whole process and responsibilities across the whole of the MSE.
Who benefits from this change and how?

It will give Divisions/Directorates reviewing the RTT pathway the ability to develop action plans based on learning from harm reviews, thus improving patient care and experience, and reducing potential of future patient harm.
